quote: To compare our method to prior work, we adopt the unsupervised KITTI depth completion benchmark, where we achieve state-of-the-art performance.
performance does not degrade by much from VGG11 to VGG8 and VGG8 still surpasses [1] and [3] while having a 89.9% and 83.9% reduction in the encoder parameters
We show the effectiveness of this approach by achieving the state-of-the-art on the unsupervised KITTI depth completion benchmark with half as many parameters as the prior-art.
We propose a new publicly available dataset for a real world use case of depth completion by bootstrapping sparse reconstruction in metric space from a SLAM system.
Our VGG11 model outperforms the state-of-the-art [3] on every metric by as much as 12.8% while using 48.4% fewer parameters.
Our full model using VGG11 produces the best overall results and achieves state-of-the-art on the test set Table II.
Moreover, our VGG8 model also outperforms [1] and [3].
our method is still able to produce reasonable results for indoor scenes with a MAE of≈ 8.5 cm on 0.5% density and ≈ 17.9 cm when given only 0.05%.
When using our pose consistency term with exponential parameterization, our method approaches the performance of our method when using SLAM pose.
we introduced the “Visual Odometry with Inertial and Depth” (VOID) dataset with which we propose a new depth completion benchmark.
Our model using exponential with pose consistency performs the best.
This result suggests that while within a small window Euler and exponential perform comparably on translation, exponential is a better pose parameterization and globally more correct.
Our VGG11 model is still has a 61.5% reduction in parameter, and our VGG8 a 73.4% over the 27.8M parameters used by [1].
